bMM7OPuSJPGiqqqGSTP_Xg.text: The service is lovely as is the atmosphere and the food and coffee are exquisite!!  Lantana rocks - my macchiato was pure perfection and the mixed mushrooms on grain toast with poached eggs yummy. I'll be back again and again!

wUBoNJIPj0clN98VD4Q3HA.text: Reasonably okay. Maybe I just have a particular (Australian) perspective, but Lantana is like a whole bunch of cafes in Melbourne. Which is kind of what they are emulating, but then it has to be assessed on that standard. So, in that particular light, it was fine - nothing special. A bit of an unfriendly, unhelpful service vibe. Food was fine, but again, nothing overly creative or different. Tricky to find, too. Charlotte Place is off Charlotte Street, if you are a bit lost.

6tyN4LacTicQ8-y2lMvAYA.text: I've been to Lantana a few times, and each time I have left dissatisfied and unhappy.  This time was no different.The Queue (bad)When you approach Lantana, it's not immediately obvious how the queueing system works.  My partner and I walked straight in and asked for a table for 2, only to be told rather rudely that we had to wait outside and someone would be with us shortly.  There was a sign on a board inside saying 'please wait to be seated'... perhaps this should have read please wait OUTSIDE to be seated....Downstairs Seating (bad)The seating downstairs is arranged as one large table which can be shared and a small two person table.  The restaurant operates a communal 'help yourself' tap water system (like many pubs/cafes) with jugs of water and clean cups so you can self-serve.  Downstairs, however, there is no place for the water jugs so if you are unlucky enough to be seated on the small table downstairs, you have to interrupt the larger table to ask for water.The Food (okay)I had the spanish baked eggs which was nice.  A little underdone but had good flavour.  My partner had poached eggs on toast, which arrived with the egg already broken (half the yolk had run onto the toast before the plate arrived at our table).   A little vigilance in the kitchen before serving the dishes would have fixed this.The Coffee (good)We both ordered flat white coffees and they were good.  Creamy and strong but not bitter or burnt.  Not the best coffee I've had in London but certainly one of the better ones.SummaryGood food, good coffee, bad experience.

K7W1eJmqGdJBnPKf_av8MA.text: This is the best breakfast/brunch place I tried during my short London visit. I was getting pretty sick of the standard English breakfast and was really happy to find such an inspiring and creative menu that Lantana offers. The maple french toast + bacon + grilled bananas is delicious. Add a poached egg for just 1,50. Their breakfast sandwiches are also delicious. But the star of the show is their toasted banana bread with ricotta. Add a poached egg to it. It reminded me of my favorite brunch places back home in NYC. We went here three times during our visit and we would have gone three more times if we were in town longer.

r-Lfnm8IZn7OrYZgEMhB0g.text: I like Lantana for some things. Like when I'm looking for a cozy place to study, I go to Lantana. When I feel like being hidden in a little back street in Central London, I go to Lantana. The coffee is good and the atmosphere is usually buzzing. However, I have to agree with many of the posters here- the people working there are just not friendly. They all just kind of look like they don't wanna be there and despise you for being a customer. It makes no sense at all. They don't try to make you feel accommodated or welcome. So... three stars from me. Lantana, please change your staff's attitudes towards customers and CUSTOMER SERVICE- or change your staff. There are many good coffee shops in Fitzrovia that manage to have both good coffee and good service (and remember, after all, that you are a BUSINESS serving and competing for CUSTOMERS).

Nq9uVNK2RM6ip9lMyIIFbA.text: I thought the coffee was good and the free wifi is always appreciated. Unfortunately they forgot that I paid for my bill and after I left, they charged my friend for it again. I haven't tried the brownies but I've been told that I should so will venture back at some point.

1k7jV3Gt0Us1OINNjAja5Q.text: For photos see the Greedy Diva @ greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  At 10am on Saturday morning, I find myself lying belly up on a purple yoga matt pondering (1) what on earth the strange smell is, (2) why the man next to me is emitting whale noises, and (3) how long it will be before I vomit, pass out or run screaming from the room in a frantic panic attack. "You must not leave the room for 90 minutes" warns the merciless Bikram yoga Lieutenant Colonel through a hazy 41 degree Celsius fog of B.O., visibly steaming body heat and dripping with sweat underarm hair. As I concentrate on the overwhelming task of breathing, she suggests that I and Libby, my fellow Bikram boot camper, wave to the room to earmark ourselves as the only Bikram first timers, presumably for the sole purpose of letting the others know which ones to watch between downward dogs for entertainment purposes. I emerge 90 minutes and a confronting communal shower later, relieved of 30 kilos of body fluid, with a traffic light red face, poodle hair frizz and a mildly startled/manic gaze, all of which suggests to Libby she best get me quickly to the nearest source of food. Lantana Cafe beckons. Behind Lantana Cafe is the story of a woman from Melbourne on a serious mission: to show the London public that breakfast can offer more than "the full English" or eggs florentine, washed down with a mug of workman's tea. As reported in the February 2010 edition of Olive magazine, Sheelagh Ryan quit her job as a policy advisor to an Australian minister, took on waitressing jobs for free on weekends in Melbourne cafes to learn the ropes while waiting for her visa to clear, and eventually found the site in Charlotte Place that now stands home to one of the most popular cafes in London. The La Marzocca espresso machine was promptly installed, and an Australian style brunch menu was put into action. And so it was that Lantana Cafe won Time Out's award for Best New Cafe 2009. Like for all caffeine oriented antipodeans, for me the key to a treasured breakfast haunt is the coffee. I'll go out for a morning coffee then go home to make my own breakfast if I must. Lantana's flat whites rate up there with the best of London's (select few) great coffee shops. What differentiates Lantana from all of them (except perhaps The Providores in Marylebone, the enterprise of 2 New Zealanders) is its typically antipodean style, hearty brunch menu. I can never go past the grilled haloumi, mushroom, sauteed spinach, corn fritter (slightly charred on this occasion), roasted tomato with chunky, wholemeal sourdough toast. The haloumi is never rubbery or tasteless at Lantana. I dined here on Saturday with Libby and Moira who sampled the alluringly runny poached eggs on sourdough. Also popular are the corn fritters, and the baked eggs with chorizo, mushrooms, spinach and spicy tomato sauce served with grilled flatbread and creme fraiche. Or you can keep it simple with toasted sourdough (with Vegemite - hallelujah) or toasted banana bread with date and pecan butter. The only downside - the hideously long Saturday brunch queue. Enjoy. Just save some haloumi for me.

FOXU5YWfsfijXMnkwCY7TQ.text: We stopped by for brunch on a Thursday, and after about a ten minute wait were seated at a tall table towards the back.  It's a small space but doesn't feel overly crowded.  It's hip but not painfully so.  Servers were nice, and the coffee was great.  Banana bread starter was delish, and the mushrooms on toast was really good.  They had some delicious gluten-free bread that my gluten-intollerant friend really enjoyed.Would definitely recommend it!

t6eHtjMb1c-fQTb86XeWNg.text: I've been going to this place since it opened.  Unfortunately it now gets quite busy (even before the Starbucks 20m away went out of busines - but especially now).Good food, good value.  Ask for a flat white (an Australian variation on a latte) but best of all try the Hummingbird Cakes.  They have recently been renamed "Lantana Crack Cakes" and have about 50% of your daily suggested calorie intake but are worth every bit.

hG22ghE1kkNJSHXdwhx9vQ.text: I went to Lantana today with some friends for brunch. We were 5 and at 11.45am, we obviously had to queue, but it wasn't that long. The lady that got our table and menus and the other guy taking our order were both very nice. One of my friend ordered a Bloody Mary and he said he was going to make it himself because he loved the drink. She said it was very good, so it was a nice touch. One of the flat whites in our order got missing and we had to ask for it again, but apart from that everything went smoothly despite the queue and how crowded was the place.The food was very good as well. Everything in the menu seemed delicious and really tasty, I wanted to try the brioche French toast with vanilla ricotta, but felt like eating something savoury, so I ordered poached eggs on toast with a side of roasted tomatoes. The eggs were perfect, but the toast was a bit too chewy. One of my friends asked it he could have some butter but he never got it (?).Overall, I'd try other places before coming back to Lantana, but this is definitely a good place to have brunch on the weekend if you are willing to queue.

IsKedj9vki0B3UnQCjZQWw.text: Why has it taken me so long to find this place?! Being tucked away in Charlotte Place probably didn't help. Another colony-originating purveyor of coffee the way it's meant to be, saving Londoners from the chains. Perhaps it's a bit too small and homely to deal with hordes craving a quick caffeine fix, but why rush? Sit back and let the anticipation build... your tastebuds won't be disappointed. Top notch banana bread too, although very pricey. Although not sampled, I did spy they also serve bottles of Coopers Ale and Bundaberg Ginger Beer.

fZ0SvWffFYl1ixWfmUobTA.text: I love Lantana. I LOVE LANTANA. I lurrrve Lantana, there's no other way to put it. Try the baked eggs or the corn fritters, you won't regret it and hey, I hear the coffee's good too!Video link: youtube.com/watch?v=puqh…

JhA5addOY9mB-vhHIVvkaw.text: A little shop in Charlotte Place where you can find lunch formulas: soups, sandwiches, pastries and hot beverages. I had £6.50 lunch box including soup, sandwich and a dessert. The warm tomato soup was very good. In the contrary, the sandwich was not brilliant (two slices of fluffy bread with cheese), it was everything that was left. The brownie was so-so as well. A bit pricey for this quality! For the same price (or maybe less), your can find much better alternatives in Fitzrovia. The place was a bit crowded and I felt I've been ignored by the waitors for more than twenty minutes. What a shame! Don't go there for lunchtime...

VyZnyWWjtSfuP6l3LSOh_Q.text: Now been there for breakfast, lunch and a quick coffee break so all that's left is to try their new late opening evenings.The food and service are excellent and has a real personal feel to it. It is on the expensive side for an informal cafe but they stress the quality of the ingredients and the cooking and so I reckon it's worth it.Certainly my go to place for a relaxed getaway and a quiet nibble in the area.

k4IkGntyodekuLBCktuc1Q.text: Sitting here with no bread in the house, I can't help but think back to happy mornings at Lantana. This fresh, Aussie-style cafe might require a wait but it's worth it, for breakfasts that deliver on flavour and, to some extent, healthiness. Don't let that put you off though: you can still get sausages and bacon and other stuff if the wine flu demands it. Personally I'd go for homemade baked beans, the poached eggs, as much of that unbelievable sour dough bread as you can handle and some cups of exquisite - as you'd expect with an Aussie barista - Monmouth Coffee. It's not cheap per se, but you get what you pay for and a late breakfast here will fuel you til evening. On that basis, I'd say it's good value. But the memories hurt when you're hungry and toastless

qmPClxRDOYYB-4SVzpRHbw.text: One of my friends took me there for lunch. She say that the place was amazing, so I went with very high expectations. The place is nice and cozy, the coffee was indeed good, scrambled eggs and mushrooms were tasty too, but sadly I do agree with fellow qypers about customer service, quite rude, as if they couldn't be bothered to talk to you... smiling and being polite cost nothing but give so much. I'd try somewhere else next time

XWP8DYU6q9IBu7YhH2gklA.text: When i first saw the reviews of Lantana (after having been there), i was quite surprised at the generally positive feelings it generated. My experience was not really the same.Lizzie got quite a few of us Yelpers here on a not so sunny summer saturday morning for breakfast. We were seated at a table outside.Since we all arrived at different times, we had only ordered coffee initially. They came and asked, a number of times, whether we want to order food ... all the while claiming that there was no hurry ... and this when the place was not full.Finally when our friends arrived and we did decide to order, they were nowhere to be found. During the whole breakfast, just getting hold of someone to ask for something was a difficulty. On one occasion when someone did come, he was visibly displeased with the starbucks cup one of us had (it was empty).The saving grace was the food. It was pretty good. I was quite impressed by the scrambled eggs on toast with black pudding that i had ordered. The chicken and corn was very good ... and so was the coffee (though Larissa wasn't impressed by hers). But the price was a turn-off. I understand that its located in a prime location in central London, but £5 for eggs and one slice of bread is simply not on.Lantana wasn't merely lethargic in serving us, they were the same in accepting their payment. After we had waited for a long time for someone to come and take the cash, we were forced to go inside ourselves and pay up.I would have given them a 2 star if i had been there on a weekday ... but on a leisurely weekend when i was chatting with friends, i wasn't too perturbed by their laziness. So its a 3 star for now ... and so it will stay, as i am unlikely to go back anytime soon.

rYXrYdcukbFvXEZjUpNzVQ.text: Reading the recent comments, I'm wondering if there has a been a recent downturn in service? Having read many great reviews about this place, I was more than happy to try it, when a colleague suggested it for lunch on Monday. We were seated swiftly - albeit in somewhat uncomfortably - my seat was higher than my companion's meaning I towered over him. Odd when you consider he is almost a foot taller than me! Presented with our menus. Drinks orders taken, followed by food. All OK so far. And that's the end of the good news. We were initially served the wrong orders, then we waited almost 30mins for our sandwiches, after we prompted a waiter. Lunch was OK, but way too pricey for what you get. Upon finishing up, I couldn't get anyone's attention to request the bill. My colleague ended up leaving me to settle up as he had another meeting to run to. Eventually it was chucked onto my table. And it was the wrong bill. I had to go to the counter to get it corrected, having failed, yet again, to attract a waiter's attention. Till service was brusque, as if the mistake was my fault. If you've been there, you'll know how small it is, so there really is no excuse for 'not seeing' your customers. I do appreciate that it was busy, but so are hundreds of other places in London. Sadly I won't be recommending this place to anyone else.

UG_2IFuHTuiGZocAhhZkBg.text: I wish they let me choose 3.5 stars.  Because this place wasn't too bad, but I wasn't exactly a fan either.I came here because of Time Out's suggestion for cheap eats for lunch.  Since I was roaming around London for 10 days anyway, I might as well check it out (I HATE London roads by the way, I can't find any streets!!)I finally got here, and it's a cute cafe.  Really cute.  And not 'cozy' like I would use for NYC cafes.  The menu was limited, I ordered a portabello mushroom sandwich.  It was nice.  It did not wow me.  I paid 9 quid for it.    I guess I'm way too used to the cheap eats in nyc, where I can get so much for under 10 bucks that this is just way too blah for me.I went to Gregg's and got a chicken pasty after.  Mmmm....pasties.

6j02lO7ci2rdiP7Qj1IE_Q.text: I had never been to an Australian cafe, and after Lantana, I can say I've been initiated. The food is spectacular; I had lunch there and had a variety of salads with really yummy chicken skewers in a sweet tomato sauce. My boyfriend had the same only the skewers where lamb, and it was perfect.  Also they do delicious coffee, probably the best i have had in London. The only down side, is that the space is tiny so at lunch time it gets really busy, but its worth waiting if you can, the staff is friendly and helpful and the process very fair.
